Title: Heard That Bird
Subtitle: A Pop Culture Intro to Birding by Ear
SponsoredBy:
- [Dr. Nicole Creanza](https://creanzalab.com/) is an Associate Professor at Vanderbilt University. Her lab studies how human languages and birdsongs evolve through time and space.
- The National Science Foundation

overview.LearningSummary: Students will learn how to use spectrograms to visualize and identify birds they hear. They will see 3 women bird researchers at different career levels model scientific thought processes and leave class excited to use the free Merlin app to ID birds outside of class.
overview.Text:
#### Driving Question(s):
1. What natural sounds are we missing as we go about our daily lives?
2. How can spectrograms be used to help us identify birds in the environment?
3. What can bird sounds teach us about human emotion and communication?
#### Hook(s):
Students will compete against bird scientists in a gameshow to identify birds in pop culture. Can they beat the experts?!

learningObj: Students will analyze spectrograms to visualize and differentiate sounds.
Students will mirror the process of real scientists to identify bird species.

lsnPrep.prepDetails:
The gameshow relies on many videos embedded into the slide deck. Make sure that your projector can amplify the video and sound appropriately.
Additionally, you might want to think about how students will work in teams during the gameshow.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Students will listen to two different bird sounds and think about what words or feelings come up.
During the initial practice round, students will learn the format of the gameshow and be introduced to sound spectrograms.
steps.Vocab: - **Sound spectrogram:**  a visual representation of frequencies in a recording over time

steps.StepQuickDescription: During the game, students can keep track of their scores in the Heard that Bird worksheet and play alongside bird song researchers at Vanderbilt University!

background.Content:
#### Connection to Research
 In this lesson, students directly follow the footsteps of scientists who are working to better understand bird communication. 
#### Research Background
 Some of our abilities we are born with, and others we learn over time. Like humans, some birds learn to sing and communicate by interacting with others in their community. Nicole Creanza’s lab looks at how these learned singing behaviors came to be, and how they are evolving over time. Learning more about bird communication helps us to better understand our own human language.

learning-chart.Title: About the GP Learning Chart
learning-chart.Description:
This Galactic Polymath Learning Chart illustrates the areas of knowledge covered. This lesson targets Science, but it helps teach national learning standards in 4 subjects: 
- [Common Core Math](https://learning.ccsso.org/common-core-state-standards-initiative); [Common Core ELA](https://learning.ccsso.org/common-core-state-standards-initiative); [Next Generation Science (NGSS)](https://www.nextgenscience.org/); and [College, Career, and Civic Life (C3) Social Studies Standards](https://www.socialstudies.org/standards/c3).
In total, there are 1 standards across US grade band(s): 5-6, 7-8.
